text: Family Member: Now, at the end of the trial catheter, how do they go uh with that? Do they have to wait for the catheter to come out in order start clinical trials or or, Doctor: That’s after you’ve sat down with D and signed the paperwork. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Then they’ll do the extra tests to see that you’re eligible. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So there are steps and then if you’re working with a urologist and he or she is able to get it out, that’s great. If they feel like it needs to stay in and that isn’t something that excludes you from the study or that just will tell me that if I’m giving you chemotherapy your blood counts can get low. If your blood counts are low and you’ve got a tube in your bladder, you could have an infection. So that I might give you antibiotics to keep you from getting an infection because you’ve got the tube in. Patient: Um. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So it just lets me be aware that I’ve got to be extra careful I’m giving you the chemotherapy. But it could be the one thing that sort of says oh he’s not eligible because he’s got a tube in his body. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Or maybe they don’t care one bit. Patient: Um.

text: Patient: And even, even this treatment – is successful or just extend me for – Doctor: Yeah, I mean other diseases we’ve had people who, uh, their cancer doesn’t come back. Okay? But we haven’t seen that in prostate cancer. Patient: Ahhh. Doctor: Okay? Patient: I mean, I didn’t even have a prostate when I got it. How did that happen? Family Member: I don’t think they always got it all out of your lymph nodes when they first harvested it. Doctor: Yeah. It had to be there before they did the surgery. Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: Yeah. Well that – it was in my lymph nodes, I know that. Family Member: Yeah. They, they harvested a couple, but then they said— Doctor: But if it’s in the lymph node, it’s in the blood stream. Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. That was his deal. Doctor: Okay?

text: Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: And it’s good for you and for me. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh, we do have, uh, uh, the one drug called, Xtandi. We have two clinical trials, and those trials are both trying to make the drug work better by combining it with other, other drugs- Patient: Hum. Doctor: That in some ways compliment the hormone therapy. Uh, both of the two trials that we have, though, do require a biopsy, and I don’t know, I’ll have to go back and look to see if they’d allow a bone biopsy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The bone biopsy for you would be similar to any kind of biopsy. They have to numb up your skin, and put a needle, and take a piece of whatever they’re trying to take a piece of. For us, the bone biopsy, the yield is much lower, meaning they don’t always get actual tumor cells, because within the bone, it’s just they’re sort of taking a shot at, you know, what they think might be the tumor. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but those trials are, are, uh, the primary hormone in this case it would be drug called, Xtandi, plus another pill. So it’s a pill-based kind of trial in that sense. Patient: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: Uh, and the, uh, the other trial we have is my, I talked before about this bone marrow transplant trial, which, um, is, you know, more kind of aggressive, uh, and kind of still in its early stages. So I can’t tell ya much about- we’ve treated two patients, and, uh, they both did really well with the bone marrow transplant. One guy has been pretty stable for, you know, going on two years, and one guy’s disease responded, and then it sort of progressed now, and he’s, he’s on chemotherapy.

text: Family Member 1: In the last two weeks. But we knew it was all for your spine, been that for two years. Doctor: Great. Sorry about that. I just needed to check. Huh, huh, so we also, you know, checked your molecular stuff and there wasn’t anything that jumped out, huh, that says that we have something that we could add a treatment to. You crying? What’s that about? Patient: Dying. Dying. Doctor: Do you feel like you’re dying or just that’s-? Patient: Well you know it’s going to happen. Doctor: Okay. Huh, you have questions, or just-? Patient: I just want to be around a little bit longer, that’s all. Doctor: Well, our hope is that as well. Huh, my sense is, you know, these next drugs we, huh, huh, can get you a little bit more mileage, and you still haven’t had chemotherapy, which could get you some mileage. Huh, there’s an IV radiation drug that can get you a mileage. Most of it’s kicking the can down the street. Huh, we’ve got clinical trials at different points of new drugs, different drugs, combinations of drugs, huh, that we could think about. Huh, yes, so there’s a lot of things out there. It’s a matter of how much you want to go through, the rest of your body, your heart, the other things can get through because the next two drugs, we pick one of them. Huh, one of them is abiraterone, which is probably the cheaper of the two. It’s just gone generic. That doesn’t mean it’s cheap. Huh, but it’s about eleven, twelve thousand dollars a month. Huh, we check with your insurance carrier to see how much they cover. Huh, are you, huh, Medicare, Medicaid, huh, regular insurance, or-? Patient: Right now. Family Member: The next couple of days he’s regular insurance, but he’s going to get Medicare the first of March. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: And that will help out. Patient: March first I start Medicare plus a supplement.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
